doc.abstracts: On August 10, 1961, Richard H. Demuth was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Robert W. Olivier. During his tenure at the Bank from 1946 to 1973, Mr. Demuth worked as assistant to the president (1946) and vice president (1947-1951), and as director of both the technical assistance and liaison staff (1951-1961) and development services department (1961-1973). He remained a member of the council of the president from 1961 to 1973. His transcript concerns his tenure at the World Bank. He discusses the importance of development banks on the industrial sector, and how they are sort of anomalous on a global scale. He discusses a case study involving the International Finance Corporation (IFC) on the development of the private sector of the economy in Chile.
